title: The Science Lab Mystery

curriculum.subject: Social-Emotional Learning
curriculum.lesson: Respecting Shared Spaces and Group Work
learningObjectives: Students will practice respectful investigation and communication
Students will demonstrate respect for shared resources
Students will show consideration for others' contributions

selObjectives: Practice respectful communication when investigating problems
Demonstrate care for shared spaces and experiments
Show consideration for group members' work and feelings

caselCoverage.self-awareness: Recognizing your role in shared spaces
caselCoverage.self-management: Staying calm when discoveries are unexpected
caselCoverage.relationship-skills: Communicating respectfully with peers and adults
caselCoverage.responsible-decision-making: Making choices that respect shared resources

intro.text: You arrive at Lincoln Middle School early on a Tuesday morning.
It's time for Science Club in Mr. Chen's lab.
The hallways are still mostly empty as you walk toward the second floor.
Science Club usually starts at 7:30 AM, giving members time to work on projects.
As you push open the lab door, you notice something unusual.
The row of plant experiments that club members have been growing looks different.
Several of the bean sprouts in their labeled cups appear wilted.
Emma and Marcus, two other club members, are standing by the experiment table.
They have puzzled looks on their faces.

beats.text: Emma gestures toward the wilted plants.
"These were healthy yesterday afternoon when we watered them," she says.
Marcus bends down to examine one of the cups more closely.
"The soil is completely dry in some of these," he observes.
You notice the lab's watering can is on the floor near the supply closet.
There are small water droplets leading from the sink toward the experiment table.

choices.text: Pick up the watering can and check if it was recently used
choices.illustrationHint: You reaching for the watering can

feedback.encouragement: You gathered information about the situation.

choices.text: Ask Emma and Marcus if they have any ideas about what happened
choices.illustrationHint: You talking with Emma and Marcus

feedback.encouragement: You showed respect by valuing your teammates' ideas.

choices.text: Follow the water trail to see where it leads

feedback.encouragement: That didn't show respect—you investigated alone without your teammates.

beats.text: The lab door opens and Mr. Chen walks in.
He's carrying his briefcase and a stack of papers.
He pauses when he sees the three of you gathered around the experiment table.
His expression shifts when he notices the condition of the plants.
"I was hoping this wouldn't happen," he says, setting down his things.
He explains the custodian heard noises from the science wing around 8 PM last night.

choices.text: Ask Mr. Chen what kind of noises the custodian heard

feedback.encouragement: You showed respect by asking questions politely.

choices.text: Suggest checking if any lab supplies are missing
choices.illustrationHint: You gesturing toward the supply area

feedback.encouragement: You showed some care for the shared lab space.

choices.text: Interrupt and say you already know what happened

feedback.encouragement: That didn't show respect—you interrupted instead of listening.

beats.text: Mr. Chen mentions the custodian described scratching sounds.
It sounded like something small was moving around.
You notice movement near the window.
The blinds are swaying slightly, even though the window appears closed.
Emma whispers and points toward the supply closet.
You can hear a faint rustling sound coming from inside.

choices.text: Step forward and offer to open the closet door
choices.illustrationHint: You stepping toward the closet door

feedback.encouragement: You showed respect by taking initiative to help the group.

choices.text: Stay back and ask if anyone knows what might be in there
choices.illustrationHint: You asking the group a question

feedback.encouragement: You showed some consideration for others' ideas.

choices.text: Wait quietly to see if anything comes out on its own

feedback.encouragement: That didn't show respect—you stayed silent instead of contributing.

ending.text: The closet door swings open to reveal a small gray squirrel.
It immediately darts between Mr. Chen's legs toward the window.
The squirrel leaps onto the outside ledge and scurries down a nearby tree branch.
Mr. Chen laughs and points to a small gap in the window frame.
The Science Club begins their morning with a new task.
They'll document the experience and figure out how to protect their experiments.
